body:
The course introduction provides a short contextual overview of the entire course and briefly mentions all five modules.


In this Evolve sample you will see the components that you should use for your personas and scenarios and some example content for each component type. Throughout this example, inline notes for SureSkills instructional designers will be presented in green.
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.1_Lesson 1 Introduction

body:
At the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Course objective 1
  • Course objective 2
  • Course objective 3
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.2_Lesson 1 Objectives

body:
IT leaders are under constant pressure to drive innovation, cost reduction, connectivity. They must also address a growing demand for business intelligence.  Just as previous technology and business shifts have changed the role of the IT leader, the new, more consumer-oriented business models of the social revolution favor a new breed of business and technology driver. These leaders are having to navigate myriad converging and disruptive technologies, align new initiatives to both business value and technology feasibility, and identify strategies to leverage existing investments to fund innovation.


Consequently, the role of the IT leader is evolving.   Many next-generation technology leaders still come from traditional tech backgrounds, but business leaders with a technology focus will also influence .  As overall business strategy planning ties closer to IT strategy, four personas of the next-generation IT leader have  emerged: the Infrastructure Leader, the Integration Leader, the Intelligence Leader, and the Innovation Leader.  Many of today’s IT leaders fit squarely in the Infrastructure Leader  persona, dedicating their time and resources to keep the lights on.  Shifting into the Integration leader role is a smooth transition for most of them, but only those with a strong business focus will grow into the Innovation Leader role.  On the flip side, many business leaders with a technology focus will evolve into the Innovation Leader and Intelligence Leader roles.


In business today, an IT leader can deliver on all four roles by upgrading his/her skills sets, business leaders outside of the IT organization can fill the roles of the Intelligence and Innovation leaders with careful coordination and integration between departments and teams, or an IT leader could have lieutenants with one or more of the persona functions.
title: Text Title

body: Throughout the #TwiceAsFast course, we will use our IT Leader personas to illustrate technology concepts, solutions, methodologies, situations, and behaviors.  Each of these persons are generalized characters, each with individual goals and needs.  Our intention in using personas is to create engaging content that resonates with you by creating examples that align with your needs, goals, and focus.

_items.body:
Here is where you introduce your persona. Who are they? what do they do?


Maria has recently moved to a more senior management role in IT operations in a large tech company that manufactures devices for the ‘smart home’. She is now responsible for managing operations that are dependent on a combination of ‘on-premise’ legacy systems and ‘Cloud’ based systems that allow the company’s workforce to interact with the applications they need.


Maria’s focus, as the Infrastructure leader, is on cost reduction.  Using 65% to 70 % of the overall IT budget, most of Maria and her team’s projects prioritize keeping the lights on and managing legacy environments. Disruptive technologies such as virtualization and cloud play a key role in cost reduction. Maria tends to focus on the technology side of the organization and internal-facing activities.
_items.title: Meet Maria, the Infrastructure Leader...

_items.body: Kai, the Integration Leader, connects internal and external ecosystems.  With 5% to 10% of the overall budget, Kai must bring together a variety of business processes, data, systems, and connection points with legacy systems and newer cloud-based approaches.  Kai’s projects touch external systems and often address post-merger integration environments.  Kai and his team are integrators and they tend to focus on the technology side of the organization and both internal and external activities.
_items.title: Meet Kai, The Integration Leader...
Meet Sefa, The Intelligence Leader...
_items.body: Sefa, the Intelligence Leader, empowers the business with actionable insights.  Her projects represent between 10% and 15% of the overall budget, which she and her team   uses to improve business-user access to information.  A key theme of Sefa’s focus includes placing the right data to the right person at the right time on the right interface.  Sefa and her team tend to focus on the business side of the organization and internal facing activities.

_items.title: Meet Alec, The Innovation leader...
_items.body: Alec, the Innovation Leader, identifies disruptive technologies for pilot projects.  Alec and his team invest 5% to 10% of the overall budget and they must drive innovation on a shoestring.  Alec and his team have business backgrounds, and they move fast, fail fast, and move on. They tend to focus on the business side of the organization and external activities.

title: EN_Scenario Example_1.3 Meet Maria

body: This is where you introduce your module. Each ID is responsible for the messaging in their assigned technology track and their personas/scenarios.
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.1_Lesson 1 Introduction

body:
At the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Module objective 1
  • Module objective 2
  • Module objective 3
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.2_Lesson 1 Objectives

body:
The IT leader persona for this module is Maria, the Infrastructure Leader.


Maria has recently moved to a more senior management role in IT operations in a large tech company that manufactures devices for the ‘smart home’. She is now responsible for managing operations that are dependent on a combination of ‘on-premise’ legacy systems and ‘Cloud’ based systems that allow the company’s workforce to interact with the applications they need.


Maria’s focus, as the Infrastructure leader, is on cost reduction.  Using 65% to 70 % of the overall IT budget, most of Maria and her team’s projects prioritize keeping the lights on and managing legacy environments. Disruptive technologies such as virtualization and cloud play a key role in cost reduction. Maria tends to focus on the technology side of the organization and internal-facing activities.
title: Text Title

body:
Throughout each module, use your sub-personas to illustrate objection handling scenarios.  Each of these personas are generalized characters, with individual objections, concerns, and priorities.  The intention behind these personas is to create engaging content that resonates with the learner by presenting relatable examples of alternative mindsets. This promotes empathy and enables the learner to effectively address and mitigate against potential blockers to their planned digital transformation.


Here is where you introduce your persona. Who are they? What do they do?

_items.title: Meet Bill, The Seasoned Line Manager...
_items.body:
Bill has been with the company for 20 years. He has a proven track record of delivering large scale software implementations and has helped to shape the company over the past two decades.


Bill is aware of your company’s initiative to implement new processes to keep the company relevant in the ever-changing landscape of software development.


Bill’s priority is ensuring that he has visibility and control over his team. He has concerns around the implementation of new practices that may damage his ability to be effective.

_items.title: Meet Anjusha, The Long Standing Client...
_items.body:
Anjusha is an account executive for a mid-level original electronics manufacturer which has been a major client for six years. She has been your point of contact for the past four years and has a good working relationship with your company.


The leadership of her company is pushing for innovative software solutions.


Anjusha’s priority is to demonstrate that she is able to adapt to an evolving industry and keep up or ahead of the competition.

title: EN_Scenario Example_1.3 Meet Maria

body: In lesson 1 you re-introduce your IT leader in context and provide an activity for the learner to assist them to achieve their goal of digital transformation.
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.1_Lesson 1 Introduction

body:
At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Identify where persona and scenario elements must be inserted into your lessons
  • Design appropriate persona and scenario learning content for use in your modules
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.2_Lesson 1 Objectives

body:
Read a story about Maria, the infrastructure leader. At the end of this lesson, you will assist Maria with the implementation of her DevOps strategy.


Click the arrows to learn about Maria and the challenge she faces:

_items.body:
In slide one, you introduce the context for the persona. What is the context? What are the issues?


There has been a history of ‘outages’ and the Leadership Team has been complaining bitterly about IT Operations not supporting the business. Maria has been brought in to ‘fix’ Ops and get them to start “doing their job”.
_items.title: The goal...
The challenge...
_items.body:
In slide two, you present the challenges the persona must overcome to address these issues. What are the priorities? How do they intend to proceed?


Maria is under a lot of pressure to get results fast. She knows that she needs to take a step back and analyze the problem carefully before she intervenes and risks making things even worse. She begins with an attempt to understand how things work in her new organization.

title: EN_Scenario Example_1.3 Meet Maria

body: Here you will provide scenario based context for a learner activity. For example:
title: Lesson 1 Activty

body:
The objective of this lesson was to enable you to Classify the benefits of a DevOps culture and Cloud First approach within your organization. This final lesson activity encourages you to put what you have learned into action.


Maria approaches you and asks for help with sketching out a plan to introduce a more collaborative approach the business. She wishes to highlight the benefits of the DevOps and Cloud infrastructure. She wonders this might solve some of the ongoing problems and encourage collaboration between Development, Operations, and IT support. She expects that this will streamline business processes and asks you to draft a short document outlining the main benefits of DevOps and Cloud.


Write a 300 word post in the discussion board outlining the main benefits of DevOps and Cloud and respond to at least two other responses in the discussion board.
title: Maria Activity Text

body: In lesson two you re-introduce the relevant sub-persona in context. You also provide the learner with scenarios for the IT leader persona to address concerns and handle the sub-persona's objections regarding Maria's plans for digital transformation.
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.1_Lesson 1 Introduction

body:
At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Identify where to insert persona and scenario elements into your lessons
  • Design appropriate objection handling scenario questions involving the IT leader and sub-personas
title: EN_Scenario Example_1.2_Lesson 1 Objectives

body:
The following story involves Bill, the seasoned line manager. 


At the end of this lesson, you will be presented with an activity in-which you must address Bills concerns in an objection handling scenario.


Click the arrows to learn about Bill:

_items.body:
In slide one, you introduce the context for the sub-persona.


Maria has tasked Bill with implementing DevOps processes in his team.
_items.title: The goal...
The challenge...
_items.body:
In slide two, you present the challenges the persona must overcome to address these issues. What are the priorities? How do they intend to proceed? 


Bill is unsure about whether the proposed DevOps approach will enable him and his team to meet the expectations that Maria has set for his projects. He is drafting process documentation to meet these expectations while adhering to the approach but he has concerns around some of these changes.

title: EN_Scenario Example_1.3 Meet Maria

body:
In the scenario setup, re-frame the challenge to the learner by providing them with a situation that requires their response. This scenario is a good chance to pose some objection handling in context to the learner. For example:


Maria has scheduled a meeting with Bill to discuss his concerns around the implementation of shorter timelines in the form of ‘sprints’. He is sceptical about the idea and states the following:
title: Lesson 1 Scenario Graphic

body: “Well, we can shorten the timelines, but with shorter times you simply have to accept that there will be more errors.”

_options.optionText: (Correct) That’s not necessarily true. Shorter timelines require achievable goals, a clear definition of done, tighter processes, and regular testing. Previous studies have proved that shorter timelines dramatically reduce error, not the other way around.

(Distractor 1) Errors are acceptable in early sprints, they can be addressed in later iterations. The goal is to deliver a working product as fast as possible. Once the client becomes accustomed to this method of working, errors will not be such a major issue.

_items.body:
Select your response. (pick one)


The answers here will probably not be in order as they are randomized by Evolve.

Correct! It is a common misconception that shorter timelines create more errors. In a traditional, waterfall development process this may be true, but with DevOps the focus is on rigorous testing and waste elimination and shorter, more achievable deliverables have been proven to minimize error.
Not quite right... If you are implementing a true DevOps process model, shorter timelines should result in less errors, not the other way around. Try again.
Not quite right... This is where you would provide specific feedback for when the learner picks the first distractor.
Not quite right... This is where you would provide specific feedback for when the learner picks the first distractor.

title: Lesson 1 Scenario Question

She wonders this might solve some of the ongoing problems and encourage collaboration between Development, Operations, and IT support. She expects that this will streamline business processes and asks you to draft a short document outlining the main benefits of DevOps and Cloud.
